reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provide life-saving assistance to improve food security of IDPs

description.narrative: The project aims at supporting IDPs affected by the recent Idleb offensive displaced in Reception Centers, open field and informal settlements, proving emergency food assistance in the form of cooked meals, covering a period up to four weeks of their immediate food needs through short-term support by cooked meals and bread. This response will provide in average the minimum 2,100 kcal per person/per day as per Sphere standards and FSL cluster recommendation. The life-saving food assistance consists in providing two meals daily with bread, in kind, to 32,000 Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) who fled from conflict areas. SARD is committed to providing the cooked meals in Reception Centers, open field and informal settlements. The action is coordinated with the CCCM and FSL clusters, as well as with the agencies managing the reception centers. At the time of the proposal, only 3 reception centers are currently operating (Al Bab, Maaret Elwhan and Azaz) and supported by SARD with provision of cooked meals, while under the management of the Maram foundation and the SAED Charity (in coordination with OCHA, CCCM, the FSL cluster, IOM and other aid actors). Currently, SARD is providing emergency cooked meals with an on-going OCHA Emergency 2019 allocation, and the funding is expected to be exhausted on 30st of March latest as the needs are much greater than anticipated. This allocation will allow 1-2 weeks overlapping just to make sure that there is no disruption of the activities between the 2 allocations, to ensure continuity of food supply to the people in need/ In order to ensure that the project sustains independently, SARD will request support cost for the operation, however, SARD has made all effort possible to keep the ratio below 15% support cost in order to get more coverage of food assistance as the needs are so great. Based on the experience in 2019, it is to note that new IDPs usually stay up to 4 weeks (28 days -30,5 average in the reception centers). Specific most vulnerable beneficiary families may remain in the reception centers for a longer period (and will receive assistance for the whole duration of the project of 3 months if requested). In total, the SCHF will support (32,000 individual x 1 month). The budget includes 32,000 x 30.5 days = 976 000 rations (lunch + dinner + bread). Additional potential donors may complete the response to face expected new influxes of displacements in the project period. The action’s contingency planning includes the capacity to face new IDPs influxes in reception centers until mid-2020.

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

receiver-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs
